#Text=OFF FOR HONDURAS
#Text=Just what Tom 's thoughts were , Ned , of course , could not guess .

#Text=But by the flush that showed under the tan of his chum 's cheeks the young financial secretary felt pretty certain that Tom was a bit apprehensive of the outcome of Professor Beecher 's call on Mary Nestor .
#Text="

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=So he is going to see her about ' something important , ' Ned ?

_	_	_	_

#Text= That 's what some members of his party called it . "

column1: #Text=" And they 're waiting here for him to join them ? "
#Text=" Yes .

column3:
_	_	_	_

8-3	476-477	.	_	_	_	_

#Text=And it means waiting a week for another steamer .

#Text=It must be something pretty important , do n't you think , to cause Beecher to risk that delay in starting after the idol of gold ?

_	_	_	_
11-2	664-673	Important	_	_	_	_
11-3	674-675	?	_	_	_	_

#Text=Yes , I suppose so ,  assented Tom .

_	_	_	_

#Text= And yet even if he waits for the next steamer he will get to Honduras nearly as soon as we do . "

column1: #Text=" How is that ? "
#Text=" The next boat is a faster one . "
#Text=" Then why do n't we take that ?

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= Well , for one thing it would hardly do to change now , when all our goods are on board .

_	_	_	_

#Text= Well , I 'm just as glad Beecher and his party are n't going with us , " resumed Ned , after a pause .

column1: #Text=" It might make trouble . "
#Text=" Oh , I 'm ready for any trouble HE might make ! " quickly exclaimed Tom .
#Text=He meant trouble that might be developed in going to Honduras , and starting the search for the lost city and the idol of gold .
#Text=This kind of trouble Tom and his friends had experienced before , on other trips where rivals had sought to frustrate their ends .
#Text=But , in his heart , though he said nothing to Ned about it , Tom was worried .
#Text=Much as he disliked to admit it to himself , he feared the visit of Professor Beecher to Mary Nestor in Fayetteville had but one meaning .
#Text=" I wonder if he 's going to propose to her , " thought Tom .
#Text=" He has the field all to himself now , and her father likes him .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=and Tom mentally girded himself for a battle of wits .

#Text= He 's relying on the prestige he 'll get out of this idol of gold if his party finds it , " thought on the young inventor .

column1: #Text=" But I 'll help find it first .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=These thoughts shot through Tom 's mind even as Ned was asking his questions and making comments .

#Text=When the chums returned from their sightseeing excursion , they found that Professor Bumper had arrived .

#Text= Where 's Professor Bumper ? " asked Ned , the next day .

column1: #Text="

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=In his room , going over books , papers and maps to make sure he has everything .

column1: #Text=Tom did not have to answer that last question .
#Text=Into the apartment came bursting the excited individual himself .
#Text=" Bless my overshoes ! " he cried , " I 've been looking everywhere for you !

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= What 's the matter now ? " asked Ned .

column1: #Text=" Is the hotel on fire ? "

#Text=" Has anything happened to Professor Bumper ? " Tom demanded , a wild idea forming in his head that perhaps some one of the Beecher party had tried to kidnap the discoverer of the lost city of Pelone .
#Text=" Oh , everything is all right , " answered Mr. Damon .
#Text=" But it 's nearly time for the show to start , and we do n't want to be late .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= For what ? " asked Tom and Ned together .

column1: #Text=" The movies , " was the laughing reply .
#Text=" Bless my loose ribs !

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=and Mr. Damon named a certain comic moving picture star in whose horse-play Mr. Damon took a curious interest .

#Text= I wonder , Tom , " said Mr. Damon , as they came out of the theater two hours later , all three chuckling at the remembrance of what they had seen , " I wonder you never turned your inventive mind to the movies . "

column1: #Text=" Maybe I will , some day , " said Tom .
#Text=He spoke rather uncertainly .
#Text=The truth of the matter was that he was still thinking deeply of the visit of Professor Beecher to Mary Nestor , and wondering what it portended .
#Text=But if Tom 's sleep was troubled that night he said nothing of it to his friends .

#Text=He was up early the next morning , for they were to leave that day , and there was still considerable to be done in seeing that their baggage and supplies were safely loaded , and in attending to the last details of some business matters .
